ecosystemDescription: Shallow warm-water marine environment characterized by extensive coral reefs, diverse fish populations, and significant sea turtle nesting grounds. Features extensive continental shelf areas with depths typically 30-200m, supporting rich benthic communities and important commercial fisheries. Area experiences strong seasonal monsoon influences and hosts critical migration routes for various marine mammals.

allGroupings.Reef sharks: Key predators in coral reef and shelf ecosystems of northern Australia, including grey reef sharks and blacktip reef sharks, controlling fish populations

allGroupings.Sea snakes: Diverse in Arafura/Timor Sea, specialized predators of reef fish and eels in coral reef and seagrass habitats

allGroupings.Coastal dolphins: Including Australian snubfin and Indo-Pacific humpback dolphins, feeding primarily on reef and coastal fish

allGroupings.Dugongs: Important herbivores feeding primarily on seagrass beds in shallow coastal waters

allGroupings.Marine turtles: Multiple species including green, hawksbill, and flatback turtles, nesting on northern Australian beaches

allGroupings.Large reef-associated piscivores: Including coral trout, snappers, and emperors - commercially important predatory fish

allGroupings.Small reef-associated piscivores: Including smaller groupers and cardinalfish, important in reef food webs

allGroupings.Shelf demersal fish: Including threadfin breams and goatfish, feeding on benthic invertebrates in continental shelf areas

allGroupings.Planktivorous reef fish: Including fusiliers and caesionids, transferring pelagic production to reef systems

allGroupings.Herbivorous reef fish: Including parrotfish and surgeonfish, crucial for coral reef health through algae control

allGroupings.Coastal pelagic fish: Including mackerels, sardines, and anchovies - important in coastal food webs and fisheries

allGroupings.Cephalopods: Squid and octopus species adapted to reef and shelf environments, important commercial species

allGroupings.Prawns: Commercially important penaeid prawns in coastal and shelf waters, including banana and tiger prawns

allGroupings.Hard corals: Diverse reef-building corals forming essential habitat structure in shallow waters

allGroupings.Soft corals: Diverse in northern Australian reefs, providing additional habitat complexity

allGroupings.Seagrass: Extensive beds supporting dugongs, turtles, and commercial fish species

allGroupings.Crown-of-thorns starfish: Coral predator with significant impacts on reef health during outbreaks

allGroupings.Benthic filter feeders: Including sponges, ascidians, and giant clams on reefs and shelf areas

allGroupings.Macrozoobenthos: Mobile invertebrates including crustaceans and molluscs in shelf and reef habitats

allGroupings.Mesozooplankton: Copepods and other zooplankton supporting coastal pelagic food webs

allGroupings.Microalgae: Including both benthic diatoms and symbiotic zooxanthellae in corals

allGroupings.Detritus: Organic matter supporting detrital food webs in reef and shelf ecosystems

allGroupings.Reef sharks: Key predators in coral reef and shelf ecosystems of northern Australia, including grey reef sharks and blacktip reef sharks, controlling fish populations

allGroupings.Sea snakes: Diverse in Arafura/Timor Sea, specialized predators of reef fish and eels in coral reef and seagrass habitats

allGroupings.Turtles: Multiple species including green, hawksbill, and flatback turtles, feeding in seagrass beds and reef areas

allGroupings.Large coastal piscivores: Important fishery species like coral trout, snappers, and emperors that prey on reef and shelf fishes

allGroupings.Medium coastal piscivores: Mid-sized predatory fish like trevally and mackerel, important in both fisheries and ecosystem structure

allGroupings.Small coastal piscivores: Smaller predatory fish including fusiliers and cardinalfish, crucial in reef food webs

allGroupings.Planktivorous fish: Schools of small fish like anchovies and sardines, critical prey species and important in fisheries

allGroupings.Herbivorous reef fish: Parrotfish, rabbitfish, and surgeonfish that control algal growth on reefs and seagrass beds

allGroupings.Benthic invertebrate feeders: Fish species feeding on bottom-dwelling invertebrates, including emperors and sweetlips

allGroupings.Prawns: Commercially important species including banana, tiger, and endeavour prawns in shelf waters

allGroupings.Hard corals: Reef-building species providing essential habitat structure in shallow waters

allGroupings.Soft corals: Non-reef building corals common in turbid shelf waters, providing habitat complexity

allGroupings.Benthic filter feeders: Sponges, ascidians, and bivalves filtering particles in reef and shelf environments

allGroupings.Crown-of-thorns starfish: Coral predator with significant impacts on reef health during outbreaks

allGroupings.Seagrass: Several species forming extensive beds in shallow coastal waters, important nursery habitat

allGroupings.Macroalgae: Various seaweed species on reefs and in coastal areas, providing food and habitat

allGroupings.Benthic grazers: Sea urchins, gastropods, and other invertebrates feeding on algae and detritus

allGroupings.Cephalopods: Squid and cuttlefish species important in coastal food webs and fisheries

allGroupings.Small pelagic fish: Coastal schooling fish like scads and sardines, key in pelagic food webs

allGroupings.Mesozooplankton: Copepods and other small crustaceans supporting coastal food webs

allGroupings.Microzooplankton: Tiny zooplankton crucial in nutrient cycling in warm tropical waters

allGroupings.Diatoms: Primary producers particularly important in nutrient-rich coastal waters

allGroupings.Symbiotic zooxanthellae: Crucial symbionts in corals and other invertebrates in clear tropical waters

allGroupings.Detritus: Organic matter supporting detrital food webs in reef and seagrass ecosystems

allGroupings.Seagrass: Extensive beds supporting fishery species and providing critical turtle feeding grounds

allGroupings.Benthic filter feeders: Sponges, clams, and other organisms filtering particles from water

allGroupings.Large zooplankton: Including fish larvae and larger copepods, crucial for planktivorous fish

allGroupings.Mesozooplankton: Mid-sized plankton supporting pelagic food webs

allGroupings.Microzooplankton: Tiny plankton essential in nutrient cycling

allGroupings.Diatoms: Primary producers important in shelf waters

allGroupings.Detritus: Dead organic matter supporting detrital food webs in shelf and reef systems
